msContents.summary: The Vasudhāradhāraṇī, dedicated to Vasudhārā, the bodhisattva of wealth, prosperity, and abundance (who has a strong following among the Newar Buddhists of the Kathmandu valley), is taught by the Buddha in Kauśāmbī to the rich merchant and layman Sucandra. He has been reduced to poverty and so requests a sermon from the Lord so that he may provide for his own family and so that all beings may become prosperous. This scripture includes a dhāraṇī along with enumerations of benefits and ritual instructions for use. This illuminated palm-leaf manuscript, dated 1123 CE and written under the reign of Śivadeva , is one of the earliest extant manuscripts of the Vasudhāradhāraṇī. According to the colophon, it was commissioned by a pious Buddhist layman, Rudākarasiṃha by name, as a meritorious gift (deyadharmo 'yaṃ pravaramahāyānayāyinaḥ paramopāsakarudākarasiṃhasya).

supportDesc.condition: Complete, damaged. Margins are often broken off in many folios, often with loss of text. Sometimes worm-eaten. The writing is sometimes faded, sometimes scratched away. The miniatures are extremely damaged.

layout.p: 6 lines per page, approximately 48 akṣaras per line.
layout.stringHole:
One string hole in the middle of a blank column.
2.2
layout.p: A pair of double marginal frame lines in black ink, enclosing the margins of the written area as well as the blank space for the string hole (and the miniature, in the illustrated folios).

decoNote.desc:
Four polichrome miniatures, now extremely damaged and consequently hard to identify, of approximately 6 cm in width, put in the right hand side of the page.
On f. 1v, unidentified representation.
On f. 2r, unidentified representation.
On f. 13v, possibly a representation of the goddess Vasudhārā.
On f. 14r, possibly a representation of a Buddha in bhūmisparśamudrā.

list.item: On the inner side of the front cover, two notes in Nepālākṣarā characters: oṃ oṃ rata and oṃ ratakaraṁṇḍaka | .
On the inner side of the back cover, a date of recitation in Nepālākṣarā characters: $ samvat_ 555 jeṣṭhaśuddhi 4 udānaraṃtamanaśibhāśacanakālāṃñ maja 7 vānaśvaśyaṃ jaroṃ -4- .

bindingDesc.stringHole: One string hole, on the left side of the manuscript.

history.provenance:
Bought in Nepāl by Prof. C. Bendall Bendall, Cecil
in 1898-9.
